question: Which renewable resource increases pollution when used to produce energy?

content.source_1: Biomass is a renewable energy resource derived from organic materials such as wood, agricultural residues, and organic waste.
content.source_2: Burning biomass to generate electricity releases air pollutants, including particulate matter (PM), nitrogen oxides (NOx), carbon monoxide (CO), and carbon dioxide (CO2).
content.source_3: Emitting air pollutants into the atmosphere increases the amount of air pollution present.
content.source_4: On power grids, adding biomass generation typically displaces fossil-fuel generation; when biomass electricity replaces coal-fired power, emissions of PM, SO2, NOx, and CO2 per kilowatt-hour are lower than those from the coal plant it displaces.
content.source_5: When a less-polluting generator replaces a more-polluting one, total pollution from producing that electricity decreases rather than increases.
content.source_6: Wind and solar photovoltaics produce electricity without fuel combustion and have negligible direct air-pollutant emissions during operation.
